Revenue from our Performance and Security Solutions was $286 million in the quarter, up 16% year-over-year or up 19% on a constant currency basis and was the sole driver of our revenue overachievement. Our Web Performance business benefited from a stronger-than-expected online holiday season. And we continue to see strong growth and demand for our cloud security offerings across all 3 geographies. Fourth quarter revenue for our Cloud Security Solutions was $73 million, up 46% year-over-year or up 50% on a constant currency basis. Exiting 2015, our security business now has an annualized revenue run rate of nearly $300 million.
Turning now to our Media Delivery Solutions. Revenue was $247 million in the quarter, down 2% year-over-year or up 1% on a constant currency basis and in line with our expectations. As I mentioned in our last earnings call, the moderation in media revenue growth rates was driven by the impact of DIY efforts in our largest 2 media accounts. However, the rest of our media business grew over 10% compared to a very strong Q4 of 2014.
Finally, revenue from our services and support solutions was $46 million in the quarter, up 18% year-over-year or up 21% on a constant currency basis. We continue to see strong new customer attachment rates for our higher-end enterprise class professional services globally. 
Turning now to our geographies. Sales in our international markets represented 28% of total revenue in Q4, up 1 point from the prior quarter. International revenue was $163 million in the quarter, up 17% year-over-year or up 27% on a constant-currency basis. The stronger dollar continued to weigh on growth rates and had a negative impact of -- on revenue of nearly $14 million on a year-over-year basis and $1 million on a sequential basis. On a constant currency basis, we continue to see solid growth in both our Asia Pacific and EMEA markets. Revenue from our U.S. market was $416 million, up 5% year-over-year. Our 2 largest media accounts reside in the U.S. and heavily weighted on the U.S. markets results. Outside of these 2 accounts, revenue growth was solid across the rest of the U.S. business. And finally, revenue through channel partners represented 27% of total revenue in Q4. 
Moving on to cost. Cash gross margin was 77%, consistent with Q3, down 2 points from the same period last year and in line with our guidance. GAAP gross margin, which includes both depreciation and stock-based compensation, was 67% consistent with the prior quarter, down 3 points from the same period last year and about 1 point higher than our guidance due to the revenue overachievement.
GAAP operating expenses were $263 million in the fourth quarter. These GAAP results include depreciation, amortization of intangible assets, stock-based compensation, acquisition-related charges and other nonrecurring items. Excluding these charges, non-GAAP cash operating expenses were $211 million, up $7 million from Q3 levels and at the higher end of our guidance. We continue to balance investments in the business with the near-term moderation in revenue growth rates. 
Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $238 million, up $16 million from Q3 levels and up $6 million from the same period last year. Our adjusted EBITDA margin came in at 41%, up 1 point from Q3 levels, down 2 points from the same period last year and at the high end of our guidance. 
GAAP depreciation and amortization expenses were $80 million in the fourth quarter. These GAAP results include depreciation associated with stock-based compensation, amortization of intangible assets and amortization of capitalized interest expense. Excluding these charges, non-GAAP depreciation was $70 million, up $5 million from Q3 levels and slightly above our guidance. 
Non-GAAP operating income for the fourth quarter was $168 million, up $11 million from Q3 and down $7 million from the same period last year. Non-GAAP operating margin came in at 29%, consistent with Q3 levels and down 4 points from the same period last year and 1 point higher than our guidance.
Moving on to the other income and expense items. Interest income for the fourth quarter was about $3 million, consistent with Q3 levels. Noncash interest expense related to our convertible debt was roughly $5 million. As a reminder, this noncash expense is excluded from our non-GAAP results.
Moving on to earnings. GAAP net income for the fourth quarter was $88 million or $0.49 of earnings per diluted share. Non-GAAP net income was $129 million or $0.72 of earnings per diluted share, $0.08 above the high end of our guidance range. Our better-than-expected earnings were fueled by higher revenues, improved efficiency and a $0.06 benefit from the retroactive reinstatement of the U.S. federal R&D tax credit in December, which was not included in our guidance. 
Without the benefit of the R&D tax credit, we generated non-GAAP earnings of $0.66 per diluted share, $0.02 above the high end of our guidance range. For the quarter, total tax is included in our GAAP earnings were $32 million based on an effective tax rate of 27%. Taxes included in our non-GAAP earnings were $42 million based on an effective tax rate of 24% and coming in about 6 points lower than our guidance range. Again, due to the R&D tax credit. Finally, our weighted average diluted share count for the fourth quarter was 180 million shares, consistent with Q3 levels and in line with our guidance.
 Now I'll review some balance sheet items. Days sales outstanding for the fourth quarter was 59 days, consistent with Q3 levels. Capital expenditures in Q4, excluding equity compensation and capitalized interest expense, were $89 million and slightly above our guidance for the quarter. As a reminder, this CapEx number also includes capitalized software development activities.
Cash flow generation continued to be strong. Free cash flow was $139 million in the fourth quarter or 24% of revenue. Our balance sheet also remains very strong with roughly $1.5 billion in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities on hand at the end of the quarter. If you factor in our convertible debt, our net cash is approximately $800 million. 
During the quarter, we spent $100 million on share repurchases, buying back roughly 1.7 million shares. For the year, we spent $300 million, buying back 4.5 million shares. As Tom mentioned, we are pleased announce that our board has authorized a new 1 billion share repurchase program running from now until the end of 2018. As we've discussed in the past, our overall aim is to deploy our capital to achieve favorable return for our investors in a manner that we believe is in the best long-term interest of the company and our shareholders.
Given our strong balance sheet and cash generation, this new authorization is intended to continue our multiyear capital allocation plan to offset dilution from our equity compensation plans and to provide us in the flexibility to opportunistically return more cash to shareholders depending upon business and market conditions
In summary, we are pleased with how the business performed in Q4 and throughout 2015 and we remain confident in the long-term prospects of growth for the company. Looking ahead to Q1, as a result of the lower volume from our top 2 accounts and normal Q4 to Q1 seasonality patterns, we are expecting Q1 revenue in the range of $554 million to $570 million. At the mid-point of this range, revenue growth would be 8% adjusted from foreign exchange movements over a very strong first quarter last year. 
At current spot rates, foreign exchange fluctuations are expected to have a negative impact on Q1 revenue of $1 million sequentially and $5 million compared to Q1 of last year. At these revenue levels, we expect cash gross margins of 77% and GAAP gross margins of 65% to 66%. Q1 non-GAAP operating expenses are projected to be $201 million to $206 million. 
As I mentioned earlier, we have purposefully slowed down the rate and pace of headcount additions and discretionary spending to align with our near-term top line growth expectations. But we are continuing to make prudent investments in the business that we believe are necessary to support sustained, long-term growth and scale.
Factoring in all these items I just mentioned, we anticipate Q1 EBITDA margins of 40% to 41%. And as I have been mentioning in prior calls, we will strive to operate the company in the 40% to 41% EBITDA range for the foreseeable future. But as a reminder, maintaining EBITDA margins at 40% to 41% will be heavily dependent on several factors, including revenue volumes, possible M&A and spending on platform capacity in anticipation of greater demand for our over-the-top video delivery services.
Moving on to depreciation. We expect non-GAAP depreciation expense to be $71 million to $73 million. Factoring in this depreciation guidance, we expect non-GAAP operating margins of 28% for Q1. And with the overall revenue and spend configuration I just outlined, we expect Q1 non-GAAP EPS in the range of $0.61 to $0.64. This EPS guidance assumes taxes of $46 million to $48 million based on an estimated quarterly non-GAAP tax rate of 29.5%. This guidance also reflects a fully diluted share count of 178 million shares. 
On CapEx, we expect to spend approximately $85 million to $95 million in the quarter, excluding equity compensation. Of course, we will continue to balance network investment against future revenue opportunity and continued network efficiency initiatives.
In closing, we accomplished a great deal in 2015 and remain confident in our ability to execute on our plans for the long term. We look forward to having an opportunity to go into more details with you about the business and future trends in the industry at our upcoming Investor Summit in Boston on March 7.
Thank you, and Tom and I would like to take your questions. Operator?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Michael Bowen with Pacific Crest.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Michael Bowen with Pacific Crest.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, if you guys could maybe go over a little bit with us with regard to the 2 customers going from 13% down to 6%. Could you maybe characterize for us how that lines up with perhaps the way you were thinking about those revenue levels maybe a quar
componenttext: So I guess, if you guys could maybe go over a little bit with us with regard to the 2 customers going from 13% down to 6%. Could you maybe characterize for us how that lines up with perhaps the way you were thinking about those revenue levels maybe a quarter or 2 ago. And maybe another way to think about it is if that revenue is getting cut in half, where do you see that revenue being made up at this point? And can you talk about perhaps some of the relative strength between media performance and also the cloud security business in that regard?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So just to be clear that the -- the 13% references, on average, what we've received from these top 2 customers, so it wasn't exactly the percentage of the business that we had in the fourth quarter, so this has been gliding down slowly for the compa
componenttext: Sure. So just to be clear that the -- the 13% references, on average, what we've received from these top 2 customers, so it wasn't exactly the percentage of the business that we had in the fourth quarter, so this has been gliding down slowly for the company. And as we said, that we expect next year it will be roughly 6%. It could be a little bit more than that. It could be a little bit less than that depending upon, obviously, traffic volumes. But we're very, very pleased with the performance, in general, of our media business. That our media business outside these 2 customers grew 10% is very, very healthy. I would say that these customers have been doing DIY for a while. And they do serve a fair amount of their traffic themselves. So depending upon traffic volumes for their businesses, we'll serve more or less traffic. But I'd say this is kind of, in general, aligned with our expectations that -- I think, in particular, what's going to fill this up, I think, you're going to go through a period where as their revenues glide down to roughly 6% of our total revenues for the company, one, we're much more diversified in our portfolio from a customer perspective because there isn't -- customers 3 and 4 and below that are not even nearly close to the side of these customers. And these customers combined are only going to represent 6%. So the revenue concentration is significantly less. There's significant opportunity for growth, as I mentioned, in the media business. That the media business is very healthy in aggregate. We believe that more and more content is going to move online. Video content, in particular, that will fuel growth. We -- our security business grew 54% in 2015. And that was only a few years ago. 4 years ago, that business was just a few million dollars. So to go from a few million dollars 4 years ago to a business now that is -- has an annualized run rate of $300 million, is huge opportunity for growth in security. And there's an opportunity for growth in other aspects of the business as well. So I think there's a many pillars of growth that we think will fuel the company, media, security, Web performance and some of the new emerging areas that Tom outlined.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe as a quick follow-up, if I may. When we had you on the road, Jim, you talked a lot about some of the contract renegotiations with some of your large customers. Typically, contract renegotiations have a negative connotation to them. But to t
componenttext: And then maybe as a quick follow-up, if I may. When we had you on the road, Jim, you talked a lot about some of the contract renegotiations with some of your large customers. Typically, contract renegotiations have a negative connotation to them. But to the contrary, you were speaking very positively with regard to some of those endeavors. Can you share with us a little bit how those efforts are going to the extent you can?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we always go through contract renewals with customers every quarter. I think what you're referring to is, obviously, each customer is unique. And the way you structure contracts with customers depends upon the circumstances for that customer. And
componenttext: I mean, we always go through contract renewals with customers every quarter. I think what you're referring to is, obviously, each customer is unique. And the way you structure contracts with customers depends upon the circumstances for that customer. And so I'd say there's nothing unique other than making sure that the contract structure is in the best interest of Akamai and the customer. And so we make sure that we do that. Sometimes that means structuring contracts differently than the way they're currently structured. But I don't think there's anything notable to talk about for any particular customer. Every customer is unique. And I think we try to come up with a solution for each customer when we work with them to make sure it's something that works for them and for Akamai.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a very quick follow-up. In the context of new competition coming into the space, do you still feel like Akamai has sufficient leverage in these renegotiations of the contracts, so that these renegotiations will be overall favorable in the prici
componenttext: Maybe just a very quick follow-up. In the context of new competition coming into the space, do you still feel like Akamai has sufficient leverage in these renegotiations of the contracts, so that these renegotiations will be overall favorable in the pricing construct of those contracts?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you talking about the customers, the top 2 customers or just in general?
componenttext: Are you talking about the customers, the top 2 customers or just in general?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess the answer would be yes to both.
componenttext: Well, I guess the answer would be yes to both.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, again, I'm not going to get into any specific customer renewal situation. I would say that I think you certainly know that we are, by far, the largest provider and the best provider of content delivery services kind of globally. And so in that reg
componenttext: I mean, again, I'm not going to get into any specific customer renewal situation. I would say that I think you certainly know that we are, by far, the largest provider and the best provider of content delivery services kind of globally. And so in that regard, I think we have a lot of leverage with our customers. But we try to make sure that when we negotiate with our customers, and we're negotiating something that works for them and works for Akamai. And so I think that's going to be the case. I think we'll continue to have good leverage. And I think we try to make sure it's a win-win for both of us.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a little bit more color on the cloud of -- sorry, the Performance and Security business? This is one of the strongest quarters, I think, you've had. Is the sales productivity improving? Is the integration with enterprises on internal bas
componenttext: Could you give us a little bit more color on the cloud of -- sorry, the Performance and Security business? This is one of the strongest quarters, I think, you've had. Is the sales productivity improving? Is the integration with enterprises on internal basis improving or any other color would be helpful, guys.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I could start with that. Maybe Tom can offer any color, if he wants. Yes, we had a very, very good quarter in Performance and Security. It grew 19%, but it grew 19% in Q3 as well. So we've been growing the Performance and Security business in the
componenttext: I mean, I could start with that. Maybe Tom can offer any color, if he wants. Yes, we had a very, very good quarter in Performance and Security. It grew 19%, but it grew 19% in Q3 as well. So we've been growing the Performance and Security business in the high-teens all year. So again, very solid performance. And as I mentioned, we had very, very good performance in the fourth quarter. One, we started acceleration in our cloud security offerings in solutions. So those grew 54% year-over-year. We had a very strong online holiday season in the commerce space. So we had a good performance and Web performance as well. So again, I think that, that category has certainly been the fastest grower for the company. And it certainly, as Tom mentioned, the largest category for the company now. So I think there's a lot of room for growth in that category.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The strong performance we saw in Q4 is all around our existing solutions in our Kona Site Defender and Prolexic, our flagship offerings. And I think what's really exciting is when you look at the road map of new solutions coming out and then later th
componenttext: Yes. The strong performance we saw in Q4 is all around our existing solutions in our Kona Site Defender and Prolexic, our flagship offerings. And I think what's really exciting is when you look at the road map of new solutions coming out and then later this year as we enter the enterprise security space that, that creates the potential to really continue the very strong growth of security solutions well into the future.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Olson with Piper Jaffrey.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Olson with Piper Jaffrey.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Along those same lines, is the upside there in security that is coming from faster uptake of security within existing customer base? Or is it faster ramp of kind of selling your security offerings to non-Akamai customers?
componenttext: Along those same lines, is the upside there in security that is coming from faster uptake of security within existing customer base? Or is it faster ramp of kind of selling your security offerings to non-Akamai customers?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's both. We have a large customer base that can really benefit from our security solutions. And security is also a great lead offer into certain verticals that may not have already bought our acceleration services. So both, I would say, are doing well.
componenttext: It's both. We have a large customer base that can really benefit from our security solutions. And security is also a great lead offer into certain verticals that may not have already bought our acceleration services. So both, I would say, are doing well.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then could you describe on the media side why or why not your other media customers outside of those top 2 customers would be able to do similar DIY build-outs and kind of less than how Akamai fits into their future media delivery needs? In othe
componenttext: Okay. And then could you describe on the media side why or why not your other media customers outside of those top 2 customers would be able to do similar DIY build-outs and kind of less than how Akamai fits into their future media delivery needs? In other words, why would that happen or not happen outside of these major 2 customers?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there's only a very small handful of customers that can even really think about doing it. We've been competing against DIY now for 15 years. Through that time, there's only a handful that have gone there. Generally, we compete successfully. A
componenttext: Yes. I think there's only a very small handful of customers that can even really think about doing it. We've been competing against DIY now for 15 years. Through that time, there's only a handful that have gone there. Generally, we compete successfully. And in my opinion, it probably doesn't even make sense for them to be doing it. And ultimately, I think that they discover that as Akamai continues to improve its capabilities, that we'll do a better job at a lower price point. So I don't think this is something that goes broader than the few customers who do it today. And even there, I'm optimistic about our future in those accounts.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Milunovich with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Milunovich with UBS.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on that question, could you talk about the timing that you expect at this point with OTT? And is there a risk that OTT will be dominated by a handful, as you put it, of customers, so you get sort of an oligopoly effect? So even if it doesn't
componenttext: Following up on that question, could you talk about the timing that you expect at this point with OTT? And is there a risk that OTT will be dominated by a handful, as you put it, of customers, so you get sort of an oligopoly effect? So even if it doesn't spread much beyond the current customers doing DIY, that if there's 3 to 5 that do it, that's basically a lot of the market and hurt your media growth over time.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The timing is really hard to predict. First, when the various offers have come out and then how popular they will be. So that's just -- it's hard to know. Our goal and job is to be out in front of it so that we're ready. And as you know, last year, w
componenttext: Yes. The timing is really hard to predict. First, when the various offers have come out and then how popular they will be. So that's just -- it's hard to know. Our goal and job is to be out in front of it so that we're ready. And as you know, last year, we did purchase some CapEx in advance of what we thought would be a real strong influx of OTT. That didn't take place the way we thought. I think over-the-top will be dominated by a relatively small number of major entities, broadcasters, carriers, media giants. I think we have great relationships with pretty much all of those folks. And we're in a very good position to benefit as OTT increases. And of course, OTT is at a situation where people are really paying for it. The quality needs to be really good. And that's a situation where the big folks, they really tend to turn to Akamai.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you still believe in the 17% compound growth rate to $5 billion in 2020, is that still a reasonable goal?
componenttext: Do you still believe in the 17% compound growth rate to $5 billion in 2020, is that still a reasonable goal?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've achieved that over the last 3 years. We are still working hard to get to $5 billion by 2020. Obviously, our projected growth rates for early this year are less than that. That makes it harder to reach the goal. And of course, we know with the foreig
componenttext: We've achieved that over the last 3 years. We are still working hard to get to $5 billion by 2020. Obviously, our projected growth rates for early this year are less than that. That makes it harder to reach the goal. And of course, we know with the foreign currency situation, with a strengthening dollar, slows us down. But -- so we're working hard to get there. Is it possible it will be a year or 2 late? Of course. But we are striving to get to $5 billion and I am confident that we can do that.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sterling Auty with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sterling Auty with JPMorgan.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with -- I'm a little confused. Last quarter, the commentary around the top customers was focused around the top 3 customers, and the qualitative commentary is that customer #2 and customer #3 were of similar size. Now you're saying it's
componenttext: I wanted to start with -- I'm a little confused. Last quarter, the commentary around the top customers was focused around the top 3 customers, and the qualitative commentary is that customer #2 and customer #3 were of similar size. Now you're saying it's top 2 and #1 and #2 are a far cry from where #3 is. What happens to customer #3 that have the commentary change?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think that in Q4, what was going on was there was a -- the growth was impacting Q4 by the top 3 customers. Customer #3 does a very, very modest amount of DIY, and so that was a different kind of dynamic, what was going on with customer #3, that we ha
componenttext: So I think that in Q4, what was going on was there was a -- the growth was impacting Q4 by the top 3 customers. Customer #3 does a very, very modest amount of DIY, and so that was a different kind of dynamic, what was going on with customer #3, that we had gone through previously a contract renewal with them. So it's less the DIY play. And certainly, only a one-quarter phenomena, not going to [indiscernible] into 2016. And if we convey that customer 2 and 3 were of the same size, then my apologies because that's certainly not the case. Customers 1 and 2 are certainly much larger than customers 2 and 3. Customers 2 and 3, just to give you -- between 2% and 3%. And below that, no customer is more than 1%. So our concentration is actually fairly limited, just to give you a little bit more color on that.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And based on the trends that you're seeing within those top 2 customers, I understand you're only giving guidance for the March quarter, but I think a lot of us are trying to think about the model and the shape of the seasonality and the impacts fro
componenttext: Okay. And based on the trends that you're seeing within those top 2 customers, I understand you're only giving guidance for the March quarter, but I think a lot of us are trying to think about the model and the shape of the seasonality and the impacts from these trends. Would you expect the growth rate to trough second quarter, third quarter? Is there any visibility around that?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we didn't specifically guide. As you know, you're right, we're only guiding for the quarter. But we did try to provide some helpful information for you without giving you a specific guide and specifically, what Tom talked about, is we expect that we
componenttext: Well, we didn't specifically guide. As you know, you're right, we're only guiding for the quarter. But we did try to provide some helpful information for you without giving you a specific guide and specifically, what Tom talked about, is we expect that we're going to see growth moderation for the next couple of quarters. And I'll leave it to you to understand what you think a couple of quarters is.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question, under the new structure, I'm kind of curious. I think it makes sense in terms of the efficiency on the go-to-market. But when you think about the development and the management of the infrastructure, what's different here ver
componenttext: Okay. And then last question, under the new structure, I'm kind of curious. I think it makes sense in terms of the efficiency on the go-to-market. But when you think about the development and the management of the infrastructure, what's different here versus other enterprise software is you have that shared infrastructure of the Akamai network. How are you going to manage the prioritization of upgrades, as well as modifications to the Akamai network that you made? You have a little bit of a tug-of-war between what the media side wants to do versus performance and security?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. Our platform organization, which includes development, deployment of resources and so forth, is not changing during the reorganization. We have already figured out how to handle the problem you suggest, where the media division needs
componenttext: Yes, great question. Our platform organization, which includes development, deployment of resources and so forth, is not changing during the reorganization. We have already figured out how to handle the problem you suggest, where the media division needs to update some software, video delivery. The security team wants to make a new product and get back out there and it's all riding on the same platform. So we have already had, on the development side, a partition of those resources into business units with product teams. And so that won't change. We figured out how to do that management, and that will continue on the same way. The difference here with this next step in our organizational evolution is that we're aligning our go-to-market resources directly with the product and development resources in these areas, and the platform organization stays the same.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Schildkraut with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Schildkraut with Evercore ISI.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd like to ask a little bit about what's going on around sort of the cloud side. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that scaling enterprise networks to handle growing cloud workloads is something that was one of your big goals. And I know tha
componenttext: I guess I'd like to ask a little bit about what's going on around sort of the cloud side. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that scaling enterprise networks to handle growing cloud workloads is something that was one of your big goals. And I know that you recently initiated a partnership with Microsoft, and I'm just wondering if you could take us up to speed on what's going on with that relationship and sort of what we might look for in the future around this.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The partnership with Microsoft has several components. I think you're referring to the part with Azure, where if you have applications running on Azure, you'll be able to check the box and deploy Akamai whole site delivery for whatever you're doing w
componenttext: Yes. The partnership with Microsoft has several components. I think you're referring to the part with Azure, where if you have applications running on Azure, you'll be able to check the box and deploy Akamai whole site delivery for whatever you're doing with Azure. And I think that's a great step forward for us. Microsoft will also be reselling our services. Now when I talk about the grand challenges, the beginning, there, I'm talking more about a business that we're just beginning to get into. And that is focused on the enterprise network, how an enterprise communicates with employees and branch offices, how you manage enterprise security to protect employees from phishing attacks or malware that gets in and steals corporate e-mails and then exfiltrates that data. We're not really doing that yet today, but that's where we are headed. We had our first really toe in the water there in partnerships with Riverbed and Cisco. And we've recently announced partnerships with a couple of major European carriers, Orange and T-Systems. But there's going to be a lot of focus as we move forward on developing capabilities for the enterprise networks. And that's different than what we do today for websites and applications, which then to be more enterprise out as opposed to enterprise employees.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. Let me ask one follow-up, if I may. Just based in terms of our research, even as workloads are making their way into those cloud platforms, people are initially being willing to go there through the public Internet. Obviously, that has a
componenttext: That makes sense. Let me ask one follow-up, if I may. Just based in terms of our research, even as workloads are making their way into those cloud platforms, people are initially being willing to go there through the public Internet. Obviously, that has a lot of issues, and 2 of them are security and performance, both of which Akamai can address. In your opinion, do you think sort of the driver for folks to come to Akamai and work with you on these cloud applications will be the security side? Or will it be the performance side?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Both, because you care about performance and you care about security. You're absolutely right in what you said. And I think that drives our business forward.
componenttext: Both, because you care about performance and you care about security. You're absolutely right in what you said. And I think that drives our business forward.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vijay Bhagavath with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vijay Bhagavath with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, Jim, stellar results here. Good news on the buyback. I have a question for both of you. The first question would be for Tom, would be the Summer Olympics, the U.S. election and some of these other major events on the planet, would these help to meani
componenttext: Tom, Jim, stellar results here. Good news on the buyback. I have a question for both of you. The first question would be for Tom, would be the Summer Olympics, the U.S. election and some of these other major events on the planet, would these help to meaningfully ramp over the traffic -- top video volumes in your media business? Or would the increment -- would the impact be more incremental? And then also help us understand in terms of any forward visibility you're getting, are any of your media customers looking to sign up contracts, capacity agreements, et cetera, to deliver any of these Internet events, add scale to the Akamai global platform?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We carry most all the major events in most all the major countries in the world. We do derive revenue from those events. Even years, you have more of those events, and they tend to be better years for our media business. And perhaps more fundamental
componenttext: Sure. We carry most all the major events in most all the major countries in the world. We do derive revenue from those events. Even years, you have more of those events, and they tend to be better years for our media business. And perhaps more fundamentally, those events, particularly things like the Olympics, there tends to be changes in the ecosystem: fancier TVs, this Olympics have a lot of 4K involved and so new technology gets demonstrated, and that tends to have a more long-lasting effect. For example, if a lot of folks went and get -- bought 4K TVs, well, I could get used it. But then a lot of content that's more day-to-day, going forward, you can imagine using that kind of capability, and that creates a lot more traffic and more business for Akamai. So I think there is a more modest, short-term impact. And yes, we do go get -- make sure we have capacity and sign up deals for all these events that is good for the media business. But sometimes, you also get a little longer-lasting effect afterwards.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. A quick follow-on for Jim would be, what steps you might be taking to systematically improve free cash flow generation? I've been speaking with quite a few clients recently. They see around a 6% free cash flow yield on the stock. How would you
componenttext: Excellent. A quick follow-on for Jim would be, what steps you might be taking to systematically improve free cash flow generation? I've been speaking with quite a few clients recently. They see around a 6% free cash flow yield on the stock. How would you benchmark your free cash flow generation versus your software Internet peers?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's -- obviously, every company is a little bit different and unique. Certainly, from a free cash flow, we are -- we generate a substantial free cash flow. We've been in kind of the mid- to high-teens from a free cash flow perspective, that
componenttext: Yes. I think it's -- obviously, every company is a little bit different and unique. Certainly, from a free cash flow, we are -- we generate a substantial free cash flow. We've been in kind of the mid- to high-teens from a free cash flow perspective, that some years, they're going to be kind of bit lower than that if we invest more effort in network CapEx to build out our network, which is hopefully, going to be for revenue that we expect in the future. But I think generally speaking, the kind of the model that we've outlined is a model that is kind of low 40s EBITDA. CapEx, in the 16% to 18% range. And then you can calculate, obviously, the free cash flow from that. And I think relative to, certainly, our peer group in the CDN industry, no one's even close to our financial model. And then relative to others that are in the software and services industry -- again, all companies are a little bit differently, but I think we fare reasonably well for companies that need to do buildout of their network like we do. So I think that we have a very, very strong business model as a company.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The organizational split that you announced, does that put the company in better position to formally split into 2 legal entities if it so chose? And do you foresee a situation where that actually might make sense? And then, as part of that question, if y
componenttext: The organizational split that you announced, does that put the company in better position to formally split into 2 legal entities if it so chose? And do you foresee a situation where that actually might make sense? And then, as part of that question, if you're now kind of aligning the parts of the cost structure into each of those 2 buckets, although I appreciate the comments you made about the platform staying as one, would you be in the position to better see this visibility on what EBITDA is for each of those 2 businesses? And do you foresee potentially breaking that out for us as well?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first question. We have absolutely no intention of splitting the company. And it wouldn't make sense to do that. And the key point there, of course, is the platform, which is common and which is a huge advantage for us, both in terms of th
componenttext: Let me take the first question. We have absolutely no intention of splitting the company. And it wouldn't make sense to do that. And the key point there, of course, is the platform, which is common and which is a huge advantage for us, both in terms of the economics and the performance and also the scale. Our security solutions, our acceleration solutions and our video delivery solutions, all right on the same platform. Our media customers buy all of those from us. So there's no intention to split up the company. And I'll let Jim talk about EBITDA and reporting.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think you know, Colby, that we try to provide you guys some color annually, anyway, around what EBITDA profile is of our media business, our performance and security business and our services and support business. So I think we already provided
componenttext: Yes. So I think you know, Colby, that we try to provide you guys some color annually, anyway, around what EBITDA profile is of our media business, our performance and security business and our services and support business. So I think we already provided that to  you. As far now splitting these up, as Tom mentioned, really, what we're doing, remember, is we're taking kind of the product management, product marketing, product development, engineering and kind of sales marketing side. And -- but that's not the entire company. There's a very, very large kind of organization in the platform, and there's other organizations as well. So we will continue to provide annually a view for you around what these divisions look like, and I'll probably -- what remains to be seen, we'll have to see at the upcoming Investor Summit what exactly we share in this construct that we're not moving into this model until Q2. So it's probably a little premature to provide visibility, but I already do provide visibility around EBITDA in the current business contract, and this release isn't fundamentally different than that other than what we're doing is we're integrating the product teams with the go-to-market teams into one team. We think its kind of drive better kind of customer-centric solutions than kind of a faster response time in 4 customers. So I think in that regard, it's more -- the goal is really to improve execution. It's not necessarily to kind of change the way we're reporting the business.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I can just get one quick follow-up. And obviously, the stock, like the broader market, has been under pressure of late. Can you see yourself pulling forward some of your stock buyback similar to, I guess, cleanups that Tom himself is going t
componenttext: Great. And if I can just get one quick follow-up. And obviously, the stock, like the broader market, has been under pressure of late. Can you see yourself pulling forward some of your stock buyback similar to, I guess, cleanups that Tom himself is going to be investing in the stock over the next 6 months to offset the stock comp that you -- which is your goal?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's why I mentioned in my prepared remarks that certainly, the primary goal of our buyback program is to offset dilution from equity grants. So that will continue to be the -- a primary goal of the program. But the way the program is set up is
componenttext: Yes. So that's why I mentioned in my prepared remarks that certainly, the primary goal of our buyback program is to offset dilution from equity grants. So that will continue to be the -- a primary goal of the program. But the way the program is set up is that we will opportunistically buy back more depending upon where the stock price trades and depending upon business and market conditions. So you can expect that if stock price is trading lower relative to kind of general market, that we will end up buying back more shares. But it's an opportunistic program and I'd say that the secondary benefit of the program is not the primary benefit of the program.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next version comes from the line of James Breen with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next version comes from the line of James Breen with William Blair.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom or Jim, just wondering if you can give us a little color around the international portion of the business. And I think last quarter, you had a pretty growth rate outside the U.S. And then maybe just your thoughts on, as you look at some of these large
componenttext: Tom or Jim, just wondering if you can give us a little color around the international portion of the business. And I think last quarter, you had a pretty growth rate outside the U.S. And then maybe just your thoughts on, as you look at some of these larger customers doing it themselves, do you think there's a greater or less potential for that to happen outside the U.S. given some sort of the geographical challenges?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the last question. We don't see, really, do-it-yourself outside the U.S. It's really only in literally a handful of giant U.S. media companies. So it's really not an issue there. In fact, it probably gets even harder outside the U.S. to tr
componenttext: I'll start with the last question. We don't see, really, do-it-yourself outside the U.S. It's really only in literally a handful of giant U.S. media companies. So it's really not an issue there. In fact, it probably gets even harder outside the U.S. to try to attempt that. Our international business, the EMEA business and our APJ business are growing at very strong cliffs. Of course, that's where we get the most impact from the strengthened dollar. So you don't see their percentage of our overall revenue growing as fast as it would otherwise.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, our international business grew 27%. So it's rolling in the mid 20s. So we're very, very pleased with the performance in both the European markets and our Asian markets.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, our international business grew 27%. So it's rolling in the mid 20s. So we're very, very pleased with the performance in both the European markets and our Asian markets.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jack Kilgallen, filling in for Heather. The first one, you made a comment that excluding those top 2 customers, the rest of the media segment grew 10%. I was just wondering, a, if you could give a little bit of color on how that metric has been tr
componenttext: This is Jack Kilgallen, filling in for Heather. The first one, you made a comment that excluding those top 2 customers, the rest of the media segment grew 10%. I was just wondering, a, if you could give a little bit of color on how that metric has been trending. And b, if you could also give some color like they price volume dynamics that are -- that underlie that 10%.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think as we've shared before that the media business tends to have variability based on traffic volumes and pushing traffic and price points. And so I'd say we had a huge Q4 of 2014. We had a record number of gaming releases, software downl
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think as we've shared before that the media business tends to have variability based on traffic volumes and pushing traffic and price points. And so I'd say we had a huge Q4 of 2014. We had a record number of gaming releases, software download releases. So the fact that we grew 10% over that, we were very, very pleased. There are some quarters where it does grow more than that, but that's when you have notably more gaming releases and notably more software downloads. But that's a very, very good quarter for Q4 outside of those 2 customers. And what was your second question?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing.
componenttext: Pricing.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing. The pricing dynamic, as we've said, with media for some time, it remains a very competitive market, which means you have to offer competitive price points. But the rate and pace of pricing -- so pricing declines do happen. They happen annually. W
componenttext: Pricing. The pricing dynamic, as we've said, with media for some time, it remains a very competitive market, which means you have to offer competitive price points. But the rate and pace of pricing -- so pricing declines do happen. They happen annually. We track them. We track them religiously. And kind of the rate and pace of pricing declines have been very consistent over the last several years.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if I could just get one more. Talk about cloud security, about the outperformance and acceleration business. So you grew 11% constant currency this quarter, which is in line with last quarter. Is there any reason we -- if that were to acce
componenttext: Great. And then if I could just get one more. Talk about cloud security, about the outperformance and acceleration business. So you grew 11% constant currency this quarter, which is in line with last quarter. Is there any reason we -- if that were to accelerate on a year-over-year basis, I guess, what would be the drivers there? I know the lower growth rate, and I know you had cited that the security products were getting a lot of the sales force's attention. Is there anything else you're seeing there maybe in terms of competition that you can shed some light on?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we were very, very pleased with -- like as I mentioned, we had a very good online commerce season. And seasonally, if you have a good online commerce season, the web acceleration business will do well. So season -- and we had a good online co
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we were very, very pleased with -- like as I mentioned, we had a very good online commerce season. And seasonally, if you have a good online commerce season, the web acceleration business will do well. So season -- and we had a good online commerce season, which why it grew 11%. That business, admittedly, in years past is growing faster than that. That business has the potential to accelerate and grow faster, but because it's a subscription-oriented business, effectively, deals you book this year tend to be revenue next year. And so I don't think you're going to expect a kind of a significant reacceleration in that business any time soon. I do think that there's significant opportunity. I think that the -- there's work being done by the engineering teams to increase the pace of innovation and start to offer adjacent products and also improve the existing products. So it takes a lot of potential on that business, but that business has been growing in kind of low double digits. It's been decelerating slightly. It is true that when you have an offering like security that's been growing 50%, was relatively new for the sales force, it's gotten significant line share, we've gotten significant traction and has taken a little bit of weight from the web performance business. But I think there's still good opportunity for that business to grow. And I think it's up to us to execute now.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on media also. First of all, on 1Q, it seems that way based on what you've got and in terms of modeling, but are we back to what we think of as normal quarter-over-quarter seasonality in the media business after a flattish 4Q? So sho
componenttext: A couple of questions on media also. First of all, on 1Q, it seems that way based on what you've got and in terms of modeling, but are we back to what we think of as normal quarter-over-quarter seasonality in the media business after a flattish 4Q? So should I think of a normal kind of couple percent down?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, I don't know what normal is at times for the media business.
componenttext: Yes. Michael, I don't know what normal is at times for the media business.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just specifically, similar to prior years is what I mean.
componenttext: Well, just specifically, similar to prior years is what I mean.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the media business declined last year kind of Q4 to Q1 sequentially. So we're certainly -- we're implying from this guide that it's going to sequentially decline this year as there have been, years past. So the Q4-to-Q1 media business has grown. So
componenttext: Well, the media business declined last year kind of Q4 to Q1 sequentially. So we're certainly -- we're implying from this guide that it's going to sequentially decline this year as there have been, years past. So the Q4-to-Q1 media business has grown. So that's why I said I can't say that there's more seasonality patterns in the nonmedia businesses that there are in the media businesses. Where those businesses do tend to show sequential declines -- I'm talking about organically, largely because of the online commerce season that I mentioned that you don't have that in the first quarter. But I'd say for media, what you saw in the guide is that, as we mentioned, these top 2 accounts are going to weigh on growth rates kind of here in the near term, but I'd say outside those 2 customers, if there is something that's normal, it's going to behave more like it did last year.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But do we still have an outside sequential impact from those 2? Or is that kind of normal -- getting normal patterns off of a 4Q where we took the big hit?
componenttext: Right. But do we still have an outside sequential impact from those 2? Or is that kind of normal -- getting normal patterns off of a 4Q where we took the big hit?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we're going to see a step-down in volumes in these top 2 accounts as well from Q4 to Q1. Are they going to be the same magnitude as they were from Q3 to Q4? We'll see. But yes, you will see a similar step-down in revenue volumes from Q4 to Q1
componenttext: No, I mean, we're going to see a step-down in volumes in these top 2 accounts as well from Q4 to Q1. Are they going to be the same magnitude as they were from Q3 to Q4? We'll see. But yes, you will see a similar step-down in revenue volumes from Q4 to Q1 in these large accounts.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the next question -- and I know it's hard to look at, but how do you think about -- if you're going from 13% of res to 6% of res, roughly, for those 2 -- top 2 into '16, what's your sense of confidence, relative to the longer term? Do you t
componenttext: Okay. And then the next question -- and I know it's hard to look at, but how do you think about -- if you're going from 13% of res to 6% of res, roughly, for those 2 -- top 2 into '16, what's your sense of confidence, relative to the longer term? Do you think -- do you feel like you're stabilized? Or should we think about those as declining businesses for you, long term, those top 2?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would view this as probably stabilizing. Hard to really predict into 2017. I think there's plenty of potential for, actually, upside there, especially if there's real progress in video over the top with these customers. So I would say, there's more
componenttext: Yes, I would view this as probably stabilizing. Hard to really predict into 2017. I think there's plenty of potential for, actually, upside there, especially if there's real progress in video over the top with these customers. So I would say, there's more upside than downside. And the very worst possible case, it's only 6% of revenue. And so we are very diversified. And I like that position because now you have some giants. The only -- a total 6% of revenue could really grow from there and help reaccelerate the business, going forward.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gray Powell with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gray Powell with Wells Fargo.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your server count really spiked in 2015, and I'm guessing that is anticipation of future traffic growth, at some point, this year. How should we think about those investments going forward? And then what kind of visibility do you have on initiatives th
componenttext: So your server count really spiked in 2015, and I'm guessing that is anticipation of future traffic growth, at some point, this year. How should we think about those investments going forward? And then what kind of visibility do you have on initiatives that could drive traffic growth higher at some point in 2016?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll take the server account. I mean, obviously, we look at network, the CapEx. And as you can imagine, we're doing deployments in the U.S., outside the U.S. And as we talked about in 2015, we did begin to forward-build for what we thought was go
componenttext: Yes. And I'll take the server account. I mean, obviously, we look at network, the CapEx. And as you can imagine, we're doing deployments in the U.S., outside the U.S. And as we talked about in 2015, we did begin to forward-build for what we thought was going to be, the potential of an over-the-top offering. And so you can think of it as the network -- we can build the network out 3 to 6 months in advance, and so we've built that out. It's fair to say we haven't monetized that here in the near term, and you'll grow into that here in 2016. So we spent a little bit more the percent of revenue in 2015 than we normally do. We normally spend kind of, call it, 8%, 8.5% of revenue on network CapEx, and we spent about 10% of revenue on network CapEx. But that's above our model. We think the model is more in the kind of 8%, 8.5% range. And we'll probably be back at those levels in 2016. And as Tom mentioned around what's going to reaccelerate media, I think we talked about what those things are. I think there's significant opportunity for growth in media outside these 2 accounts. We do believe one catalyst for growth in the media businesses is that more and more premium content moves online, it's poised to push a lot more traffic online, and we believe that we're in a good position to benefit from that when that happens.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the visibility question. I think we probably have as good visibility as it's possible to have. And that said -- but it's hard to predict the future. And there's, I think, things that happen or don't happen that are even beyond the industr
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the visibility question. I think we probably have as good visibility as it's possible to have. And that said -- but it's hard to predict the future. And there's, I think, things that happen or don't happen that are even beyond the industry to really know for sure. We got caught a little bit last year with that. We and a lot of other folks have very good reason to believe that there was going to be the good possibility of a large influx in OTT traffic. That did not take place. So generally, I say, our visibility is very good. We are very well connected with all the major players, but it's not perfect.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And then I just want to make sure I have something correct from a modeling perspective. You may have already touched on this already, but how much of the impact from your top 2 customers going from 13% of revenue to 6% is actually
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And then I just want to make sure I have something correct from a modeling perspective. You may have already touched on this already, but how much of the impact from your top 2 customers going from 13% of revenue to 6% is actually hitting in Q1? Is it all hitting in Q1? Or is it phase in over the next 2 or 3 quarters?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. As we mentioned, the sort of 13% is kind of, call it, average over the last few years. It's been coming down. So in Q4, it was not. It was lower than 13%. And as Tom mentioned, that we think that you're going to see it come down probably through the m
componenttext: No. As we mentioned, the sort of 13% is kind of, call it, average over the last few years. It's been coming down. So in Q4, it was not. It was lower than 13%. And as Tom mentioned, that we think that you're going to see it come down probably through the middle part of 2016. And then our -- we'll have to see our expectation is that we think it may stabilize from there.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from line of Gregg McDowell with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from line of Gregg McDowell with JMP Securities.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rishi Jaluria, dialing in for Gregg McDowell. So first, I mean, you discussed your strong e-commerce season that you had over the holiday seasons, and I believe it was IBM that said that almost 60% of Internet shopping came from mobile devices. Ju
componenttext: This is Rishi Jaluria, dialing in for Gregg McDowell. So first, I mean, you discussed your strong e-commerce season that you had over the holiday seasons, and I believe it was IBM that said that almost 60% of Internet shopping came from mobile devices. Just wondering how -- what sort of impact have you seen from the shift of Internet traffic to mobile devices?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw very similar statistics. I think our statistics were just a little bit less. That could be with our customer mix. We do carry almost all the major commerce sites on our platform. But mobile is certainly increasing its penetration. We're puttin
componenttext: Yes, we saw very similar statistics. I think our statistics were just a little bit less. That could be with our customer mix. We do carry almost all the major commerce sites on our platform. But mobile is certainly increasing its penetration. We're putting a lot of effort into improving mobile performance. Mobile performance is more challenged, obviously, than desktop performance, especially if you're using a cellular network. And there's a lot of interest in our commerce customers, our customer base as a whole, in mobile site performance and mobile app performance.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. Okay. And then you've seen some impressive growth from or cloud security business. I mean, there aren't really many cloud security players out there with $300 million in annual revenue. Just as you've gotten to this sort of scaling, and yo
componenttext: Got it, got it. Okay. And then you've seen some impressive growth from or cloud security business. I mean, there aren't really many cloud security players out there with $300 million in annual revenue. Just as you've gotten to this sort of scaling, and you continue to grow this relatively high [indiscernible]. Do you anticipate that you're going to start running into bigger competitors, especially they kind of take notice of this big growing business?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a lot of folks interested in the security business. There's giant security companies that license software or sell you a hardware. We come at it from a really different approach, where we have built a fantastic platform that we can use in
componenttext: I think there's a lot of folks interested in the security business. There's giant security companies that license software or sell you a hardware. We come at it from a really different approach, where we have built a fantastic platform that we can use in a multi-tenant way to provide excellent security with excellent performance and a very-easy-to-consume manner. And there, the big folks don't know how to do that as we have got a great headstart there and we've got 15 years of experience operating in that kind of platform. So there's just lots of customers around Cisco and signed up, and it's up to us to execute there. Plenty of competition all around. But in cloud security, we have a very good value proposition.

componenttext: I just want to revisit the realignment of your -- of the business. Just to get sort of clear understanding of -- there's a rationale sort of why you're putting the change into place. And maybe it would be helpful if you could walk us through a couple of examples of the types of stuff you're expecting to be able to do with the new alignment that you couldn't do with the old alignment. Just help us understand sort of the reason why.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think whenever you bring the customer closer to the developer, you get a better result. You make better products, you make them faster, innovation gets in the customer's hands faster. You're more efficient. And that's what we're trying to accomplis
componenttext: Yes, I think whenever you bring the customer closer to the developer, you get a better result. You make better products, you make them faster, innovation gets in the customer's hands faster. You're more efficient. And that's what we're trying to accomplish here. We are getting our -- the folks that work day-to-day with customers lined up right next to the developers that make the products for them. As you can imagine, there's a very high correlation between the revenue we get from media customers and the revenue we get from our media products. And on the other side of the house, a very strong correlation from -- between the revenue we get from, say, banks and commerce sites, as customers and the revenue we get from our application acceleration and web security products. So by bringing those teams together, I think we will be more responsive to our customers and more efficient, overall, and I think it helps us accelerate growth.

componenttext: That's right. I think we want to view this as cost-neutral. We weren't doing this in terms of absolutely saving dollars. We're not doing a big layoff here. But I do expect us to be a lot more efficient, and I do expect that to help us, ultimately, on the bottom line for the company.

componenttext: No. That's important, we put a lot of effort into that as we planned this realignment. I think we have less than 0.5% of our customers that won't have any change in their account team. I think 96% of the reps still have exactly the same territory, and that's probably more than you might even see in typical years. So there's not really any disruption on the customers side. It's just that those teams will have their management change now side-by-side with the developer management change. And so I think you'll see us be more effective as a result.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I recognize it sounds like the pressure your top 2 customers is -- you think principally due to do-it-yourself efforts. But I wonder if you could comment on what you're seeing more broadly in the media delivery business competitively from the lik
componenttext: Yes, no, I recognize it sounds like the pressure your top 2 customers is -- you think principally due to do-it-yourself efforts. But I wonder if you could comment on what you're seeing more broadly in the media delivery business competitively from the likes of Amazon, Level 3, EdgeCast or the private players outset, et cetera? Any sense of share loss or any sense of changing dynamics on that front that may be pressuring the business?

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, not really. We've got dozens of competitors in the media space. We always have. We always will. There's just so much potential on that space that you're going to have a lot of competitors. I think we compete very effectively. I'm not aware of any sig
componenttext: Yes, not really. We've got dozens of competitors in the media space. We always have. We always will. There's just so much potential on that space that you're going to have a lot of competitors. I think we compete very effectively. I'm not aware of any significant share loss there. I think the only fundamental shift there really has been with the big carriers. And basically, I'd say, the shift has been more towards standardizing on Akamai. I think you look back 4 or 5 years ago, most of the world's major carriers had some kind of DIY effort to build their own CDN to compete with Akamai. Maybe they've bought a lot of equipment from one of the big box manufacturers. And today, most of the world's major carriers are pretty much standardizing on Akamai. Obviously, Verizon, an exception, they're having purchase EdgeCast we compete with as I've said Verizon still a very large reseller for Akamai. Level 3, of course, competes, always have. The list is not long in terms of the carriers. The cloud providers, some of them partner with us, some of them have competing services. But we're not seeing erosion due to competition. We got 2 large customers that are built out more of their own internal effort. We have not lost business to competitors there. So I think we're very -- in a very good position on the competitive front.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Akamai Technologies Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Barth, Head of Investor Relations. Sir, please go ahead.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Liz, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining Akamai's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. Speaking today will be Tom Leighton, Akamai's Chief Executive Officer; and Jim Benson, Akamai's Chief Financial Officer.Before we g
componenttext:
Thank you, Liz, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining Akamai's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. Speaking today will be Tom Leighton, Akamai's Chief Executive Officer; and Jim Benson, Akamai's Chief Financial Officer.
Before we get started, please note that today's comments include forward-looking statements, including statements regarding revenue and earnings guidance. These forward-looking statements are subject to risk and uncertainties and involve a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Additional information concerning these factors is contained in Akamai's filings with the SEC, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The forward-looking statements included in this call represent the company's view on February 9, 2016. Akamai disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances.
As a reminder, we will be referring to some non-GAAP financial metrics during today's call. A detailed reconciliation of GAAP and non-GAAP metrics can be found under the financial portion of the Investor Relations section of our website.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Akamai Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and thank you all for joining us. Q4 was another strong quarter for Akamai on both the top and bottom lines. Revenue in the fourth quarter was $579 million, up 8% year-over-year and up 11% when adjusted for foreign exchange headwinds. Our rev
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and thank you all for joining us. Q4 was another strong quarter for Akamai on both the top and bottom lines. Revenue in the fourth quarter was $579 million, up 8% year-over-year and up 11% when adjusted for foreign exchange headwinds. Our revenue overachievement compared to guidance was driven by the continued rapid growth of our security services, as well as a strong holiday commerce season.
Non-GAAP EPS for the fourth quarter was $0.72 per diluted share, up 3% year-over-year and up 5% when adjusted for currency headwinds. Our better-than-expected earnings were fueled by higher revenues, improved efficiency and a $0.06 benefit in the reinstatement of the federal R&D tax credit. 
We also had very strong cash generation in the fourth quarter with free cash flow of $139 million. Our fourth quarter results capped off another excellent year for Akamai. In 2015, we generated $2.2 billion in revenue, up 16% in constant currency over an outstanding 2014. As a result, Akamai is now one of only 11 U.S. public Internet software and services companies that has generated over $2 billion in annual revenue.
Our Performance and Security Solutions topped $1 billion in revenue in 2015, making this our largest solution category. Contributing to that result were our Cloud Security Solutions, which grew 54% for the year and now have an annual revenue run rate of nearly $300 million. We continued to be very profitable in 2015, generating non-GAAP net income of $454 million or $2.52 per diluted share, up 6% over 2014 in constant currency.
I believe our excellent 2015 financial performance demonstrates that our business is strong, growing and highly profitable, validating our comprehensive strategy to make the Internet fast, reliable and secure for our customers.
